item.title: Group
item.description: The concept of a group was invented to capture the abstract properties of symmetries (i.e. transformations that preserve internal ‘structure’) of geometrical objects. These transformations must be composable in the following coherent way. Definition. A group is a tuple $\tpl{G,\cdot,e,\iota}$ consisting of underlying set $G$, a distinguished element $e\in G$ called the identity, and operations $\cdot:G\times G\to G$ and $(\slot)^{-1}:G\to G$, subject to the following conditions. (Associativity). For all $g,h,k\in G$, we have $g\cdot(h\cdot k)=(g\cdot h)\cdot k$.

item.title: Metric Space
item.description: Abstracting away the basic properties of Euclidean distance in $\R^n$, and most notably preserving the Triangle Inequality, we make the following Definition. A metric on a set $X$ is a function $d:X\times X\to\R_{\geq0}$ such that (Positive-definiteness). For all $x,y\in X$, we have $d(x,y)=0$ iff $x=y$. (Symmetry.) For all $x,y\in X$, we have $d(x,y)=d(y,x)$. ($\Delta$-inequality). For all $x,y,z\in X$, we have $d(x,z)\leq d(x,y)+d(y,z)$. If $d$ is a metric on $X$, we call the pair $\tpl{X,d}$ a metric space.
